body.p: Hippocampal place cells have been studied for more than 40 years, yet the mechanisms underlying their remarkable spatial tuning are still not established. Using whole-cell patch-clamp recordings in freely moving rats, Lee et al. (p. 849) changed the baseline membrane potential in hippocampal pyramidal neurons. Place fields arose spontaneously in otherwise silent pyramidal cells after depolarization when the membrane voltage reached a threshold. Place cells in the hippocampus and grid cells in the entorhinal cortex are thought to provide the framework for spatial navigation in an animal. However, it is still unclear how the hexagonal symmetry that is so prominent in grid cells emerges. While recording from the entorhinal cortex and in the pre- and parasubiculum during spatial behavior in the rat, Krupic et al. (p. 853) discovered that many forms of spatial periodicity exist in neurons in these structures. The grid cells seem to reflect a subset of this larger set, generated by self-organized dynamics.
